timeline.text: This is a teenager. (We'll call him Alex.)

It's 1997. Bill Clinton will start his second term as US president. Men In Black and Titanic will be released in theaters. And humans will land a rover on Mars. But Alex has other things to worry about.

Alex is a 13-year-old Hispanic kid being raised by his dad and step-mom.


Neither parent has a college degree. Their household income is below the poverty line. And their family's net worth is less than $2,000.


When asked about his mom and dad's parenting style, he said they were not very supportive and not very involved.

In fact, there were many indications that his home environment was pretty bad.


Researchers asked him and his parents a bunch of questions about his home and family life, and assigned him a "risk score". He scored way above average.


>> Histogram: About 90% of kids had a score of 4 or lower. Alex had a risk score of 7.

A year from now, in 1998, a researcher named Vincent Felitti will publish a paper that drastically changes the way we think about Alex – and his childhood. The research will tell us that these childhood stressors and traumas have a big impact on our lives as adults – our health, income, and pretty much everything else.

Over the next 25 years, researchers will interview Alex regularly. So we'll know how hard his life gets.


He'll be bullied at school. 


He'll be held back a few grades.


He'll be the victim of a violent crime. 


Many years from now, when he's an adult, Alex will tell the researchers that he struggles with his physical and mental health.

But, for now, Alex is a teenager.


And he's pretty optimistic about his future – just like most teenagers. Let's meet them now.
See!? These teens are very optimistic.

In this story, we'll track hundreds of teenagers for the next 24 years, nearly into their 40s. They're among the thousands of kids who are part of the National Longitudinal Survey of Youth, which basically means researchers tracked them over several decades by regularly asking lots of questions. For so many kids, there is a remarkable contradiction in their lives. On one hand, they do what most kids do – go on first dates, hang out with friends, and just be optimistic about their futures. But that's a sharp contrast with the several hardships so many of them endure: dysfunctional homes, proximity to violence, death of loved ones, academic struggles, and more. Ever since Felitti's groundbreaking paper, researchers have studied childhood trauma and stressors – dubbed Adverse Childhood Experiences, or ACEs. They've since learned that children who experience ACEs, especially in early childhood, are more likely to experience a lifetime of mental, physical, and social problems. The idea that childhood trauma has lifelong effects is now mainstream, to the point that it's now being called "trendy" to talk about it. But for kids, these traumas and stressors are part of the life they were born into. Eventually, they'll become adults who have more agency – but by then, their bodies and minds will already have been changed forever.

Most kids grew up being raised by two parents who were involved in their lives, for better or worse. But a notable portion of these kids, including Alex, described parents who displayed an uninvolved parenting style. A 2018 study found that uninvolved parents "show less warmth, place fewer restraints on and display little monitoring of children’s behavior." The researchers said that it resembled a "neglectful parenting style."

Research from 1994, shortly before this survey, found that poor kids who grow up in safe, supportive, and organized homes tend to be more resilient. More recent research found that unstable and chaotic home environments can erode the ability of kids to manage their emotions. These environmental factors were captured in several questions in this survey, and turned into an overall home and family "risk" score. > Chart: Most kids got a 0, and about 75% of kids received a risk score of less than 2.

timeline.text: Kids who grow up in a poor family are far more likely to experience childhood trauma. Some researchers argue that poverty, in and of itself, is an Adverse Childhood Experience. And it's not just about your own family: Growing up in a poor neighborhood can also increase your risk of trauma. In 1997, about 18% of kids lived in poverty.

There are many other stressful or traumatic things a kid can experience. While this survey didn't ask about everything, it did ask about…
  • Uninvolved parents
  • High home risk score
  • Family lived in poverty
  • Held back in school
  • Suspended from school
  • Experienced homelessness
  • Parents divorced
  • Parent, sibling, or partner dies
  • Bullied by peers
  • See someone shot with a gun
Let's call these "traumatic experiences" – and let's track how many of these people experience over the next several decades.

Most of these kids are 13, but as they get older, they'll experience more of these difficult things.


Let's go forward in time.

Let's check in on Alex.


He's 15 now, and he's experienced a lot of bad things thus far.


TK, TK, and TKTKTK.
But, hey, he just had his first date!
In fact, this is about the age when lots of kids go on their first date.
OK, back to tracking trauma.

Now it's 2001.


TKTK something about 9/11?

Even at this early of an age, we can see how much these factors shape a kid's life.


Let's see what happens when we rearrange them by their high school GPA – lower GPAs on the left, higher on the right.
You can see that kids who have had tough lives tend to do worse in school.
It's 2002, and a lot of kids are starting to go to college.

We can already see that colleges are more likely to be filled with people who were able to follow the traditional path for success – people who were able to experience childhood, rather than have to deal with so much adult shit.

When a kid turns 18, they're considered an adult. It's an arbitrary age; their brains are still developing, they're still figuring out what they want to do in life, and they often need to learn how to do basic things, like feed themselves. In 2000, psychologist Jeffrey Arnett published a paper arguing that there's a distinct era between ages 18 to 25 that is neither adolescence or adulthood. He dubbed it "emerging adulthood."
Emerging adulthood is a time of life when many different directions remain possible, when little about the future has been decided for certain, when the scope of independent exploration of life's possibilities is greater for most people than it will be at any other period of the life course. … Emerging adults tend to have a wider scope of possible activities than persons in other age periods because they are less likely to be con- strained by role requirements, and this makes their demographic status unpredictable.
Arnett wasn't the first to think up this idea. He cited German psychoanalyze Erik Erikson, who wrote about the "psychosocial moratorium" that developed countries give to young people. It's a period "during which the young adult through free role experimentation may find a niche in some section of his society." But lots of teens never get to have a period of emerging adulthood, which tends to happen in college. Many of them are forced to jump straight into the workforce, or they're in the painful limbo between high school and, well, whatever comes after. Over the last TK years, Arnett argues that emerging adults have delayed adulthood. More people are going to college: People are getting married later in life: And people are having kids later in life: So most of these kids have plenty of time. But… not all. In fact, let's see how many of these people have young kids of their own.

Let's color people in by their highest degree thus far. 


As you can see, college degrees are far more common among people who have had a fairly smooth life thus far.

I'm about these people's age, and when we were growing up, we were told two conflicting messages.


One was that college is super important.


The other was that not everyone has to go college. Every adult had stories about how someone they know found successful, well-paying jobs without a college degree. My school offered vocational programs to help people become mechanics, chefs, and woodworkers.


But here's the problem: Starting in the 1980s, when these people were born, college degrees started becoming basically a requirement for a middle-class life. Over the last TK years, college graduates were able to sustain their income levels, while people without degrees started to earn less and less:


>>> CHART


Meanwhile, people with college degrees got happier, while people without degrees said they were less happy.


>>> CHART


But during this period, the cost of college skyrocketed.


>>> CHART


And it drowned this generation in debt:


>>> CHART

It's 2013 – about 16 years since we first started tracking these people.


Every few years, the researchers asked about their general health.

What we can see is TKTKTKTKT – just like Felitti found TKTKT years ago, and what TKTKT researchers found since.


Most people on the page have yet to turn 30, but as they aged, the interviews shows that more health problems emerged for people who experienced more trauma.

timeline.colors: Down or blue in past month
timeline.text: Down or blue
Happy person in past month

It's 2019. TKTKTKT. In one year, the world will experience a global pandemic. It will tear through the social and economic stability of virtually every country. It will decimate the mental health of billions of people. It will kill TKTKTKTK people.
It's 2021 – the latest year we have data for. Let's try sorting by income.
TKTKTK income.
A huge reason TKTKT leftover. Left behind.
Now health…
One thing that is clearly visible after all these years is that race had a huge part to play in how much trauma you experienced throughout your life.
So, how is Alex doing?
TKTKTK TKTKKTK TKTKTK

As a teenager, I didn't understand what my politics were. I vaguely knew that people around me thought liberals were bad; I remember my classmates teasing a history teacher who was a self-identified liberal. But I didn't understand how your opinion on issues like abortion, taxes, and affirmative action were related to one big label like "liberal" and "conservative."


I went to college in New York, and I learned about what it means to be a liberal and a conservative. People around me were liberal – people I thought were good, smart people – so I absorbed their politics. And eventually I ended up reporting on politics.


To be honest, it was miserable. Politics is important, but talking to people who care about politics was completely uninteresting. I could predict their answers, their complaints, their frustrations. When Trump was elected, it only highlighted the political divide between the Red team and Blue team.


It was only after I left newsrooms that I started to re-articulate what I believe and why I believe it.


And, for me, so much of it comes down to the story you see here: 


This is a teenager. She has inherited her circumstances, and she has inherited the problem of this world. In the next 25 years, she will experience some terrible things. In fact, most teenagers will go through some traumatic events, because that's a part of life.


I want to live in a world where people have the resources and support to wade through those terrible things, to have a chance to figure out what role they want to play in the world, to have a chance to play and explore and, honestly, mess up.


The gap between that world and reality is my politics. It's why I left newsrooms to teach full-time. It's why I'm drawn to stories like this. And it's TKTKTKTKTK.

Explore the data

Color and sort these people however you want using the pulldown menus on the bottom-right.
